urn:contentItem:5WP6-6CK1-DY1R-B3TH-00000-00Bitcoin nears tipping point and bearish signs abound2019-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:12ZLexisNexisBitcoin nears tipping point and bearish signs abound


Bitcoin may be closer to a tipping point as cryptocurrencies struggle with increased oversight and bearish signs accumulate. Some technical indicators for the world's largest digital currency foresee further losses.

It has fallen below his 50-day movingaverage, which could indicate an end to a recent uptrend that brought him closer to $14,000 at the end of June.
In addition, the bitcoin has fallen below the lower limit of the GTI Vera Bandindicator, which measures up and down trends, and traded at about US$9,575 at 12:16 p.m. in New York.
The bitcin "is at a key technical juncture," Wrote Matt Maley, Miller Tabak + Co. securities strategist, in a recent note. Increased regulatory oversight "will become an even more important (much more important) problem when we pass the congressional summer recess and enter the 2020 election cycle."
 
A number of negative events have brought down cryptocurrencies this month, including the repercussions of Facebook Inc.'s plans to launch its own stablecoin called pound. Lawmakers criticized David Marcus, who leads the company's blockchain team, during back-to-back statements to Congress earlier this month, citing trust and privacy issues, among other issues.
The crypto-launch of the social media giant comes at an inopportune time: the U.S. Department of Justice announced plans to investigate the big tech platforms following criticism that some companies have become too great and powerful." It's a new product. It's very different from most new products," said JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade. "Everyone, including regulators, is trying to find the best way to implement this to protect people, keep it viable, but prevent it from turning into the wild west." And last week, the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS) warned more than 10,000 cryptocurrency holders that they may be subject to penalties for evading taxes on their investments. Bitcoin has dropped by 20% this month. Other cryptocurrencies have also been devalued: Litecoin has fallen by more than 25% in the same period, while the ether has dropped by about 32%. A Senate banking committee will hold a hearing Tuesday entitled "Review of regulatory frameworks for digital currencies and blockchains."
The Bitcoin entry is approaching tipping point and abounding bearish signs was first published in The Third.

urn:contentItem:5WDK-FGS1-F021-62VM-00000-00Bitcoin passes $11,000 on news of Facebook's cryptocurrency plan;The original cryptocurrency hits 15-month high as traders bet move will legitimise sector2019-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:12ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGYVersion:2Bitcoin passes $11,000 on news of Facebook's cryptocurrency planThe original cryptocurrency hits 15-month high as traders bet move will legitimise sectorRichard Partington Economics correspondent

The price of bitcoin has surged above $11,000 (£8,600), its highest level in 15 months, amid renewed hype over cryptocurrencies after Facebook said it was planning to launch a digital currency next year.

Bitcoin has risen in value by almost $2,000 in the week since the US technology firm revealed plans to create a cryptocurrency called Libra, in a move that could radically reshape the financial landscape with far-reaching implications for governments and central banks around the world.

The original cryptocurrency had languished below $6,000 for much of this year and was falling out of the headlines as investors around the world gradually lost interest in the fad for digital assets.

Some investors had been severely burned by bitcoin when its meteoric rise to almost $20,000 in late 2017 - which drew comparisons to the tulip mania of the 17th century - was followed by a spectacular collapse last year.

Stoking fresh fears of the reinflation of the bubble, bitcoin hit $11,116.65 over the weekend, up from $8,539.81 at the start of June, before dropping back slightly to trade at about $10,800 on Monday afternoon.

Analysts said the news of Facebook's work on Libra was the prime driver behind the surge, as traders bet the adoption of cryptocurrency technology by a major global corporation would help legitimise the industry.

Craig Erlam, a senior market analyst at the financial trading firm Oanda, said: "Bitcoin has slowly - by its own standards - been rising in recent months but the launch of Facebook's Libra has clearly been a catalyst for the recent surge.

"The publicity that the launch has once again brought to the space, combined with the legitimacy it offers, has understandably excited the community."

Rising tensions in the   Middle   East and mounting fears about the world economy have also stoked renewed interest among investors in bitcoin, which is sometimes viewed as a safe-haven asset similar to gold. The digital currency does not typically mirror the movements in wider financial markets during periods of turmoil.

Gold prices have risen in recent weeks to the highest levels since 2013, as the US Federal Reserve could be forced into interest rate cuts to stave off a slowdown in the US economy. The   European Central Bank has also   said it could cut interest rates as growth falters in the eurozone.

Unlike its run in 2017, which came largely from media hype stoking retail investors' interest in cryptocurrencies, bitcoin's tripling in value this year could have been the result of increased demand from professional investors such as fund managers and hedge funds.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange last week recorded an all-time high volume of trading in bitcoin derivatives contracts - sophisticated investments tracking the price of the digital currency only available to City banks and fund managers - with more than 5,000 contracts worth $250m.

However regulators around the world have warned that Facebook's entry into the world of cryptocurrencies could lead to greater controls and tougher regulations to protect consumers.

Mark Carney, the governor of the Bank of England, gave a cautious welcome to Libra last week. He said the central bank would support new entrants into the UK financial system, but warned that Facebook would need to meet the highest regulatory standards.

"The Bank of England approaches Libra with an open mind but not an open door," he said.

At the weekend the Bank for International Settlements warned that big tech firms using digital currencies could undermine the stability of a banking system that had only just recovered from the crash of 2008.

Analysts at the Swiss bank UBS said: "We continue to view speculation in specific cryptocurrencies as a gamble and not an investment. Investors interested in next-generation payment systems should consider [other] emerging opportunities."

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, February 6th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Breaking news this morning the global sell-off is continuing, futures are indicating a decline at the start of trading this morning of 182 points as three-quarters of 1 percent. And I should point out that that is off of the lows this morning. The NASDAQ is down 15 and the S&P is down six, this comes of course after stocks tumbled yesterday with the Dow posting the largest single-day point decline ever closing down nearly 1,200 points on the day that wasn't the low. The Dow and the S&P 500 wiped out the year's gains with yesterday's performance alone. The declines sending shockwaves across the world overnight and this morning.

First overnight take a look at Asia overnight, markets tip a nose-dive the worst performers were Japan and Hong Kong with the Hang Seng index down better than five percent and the Nikkei average in Japan down four and three-quarters percent. And then there's Europe, markets are open right now and they are trading down. You got steep declines across the board in Europe, the FT 100 down 1.8 percent as you can see the market there hitting the lowest level in over a year. The CAC Quarante is down 2-2/3 percent and the DAX Index down 2-1/4 percent. The turmoil coming as investors are watching earnings this morning from some big names.

General Motors reported earnings and revenue that were above expectations for the fourth quarter. G.M. stock is up 1-1/2 percent, we're also watching Disney because the Walt Disney company is going to be reporting its fourth quarter after the close tonight. We're also watching shares of I'm sorry Bitcoin, the price of Bitcoin is down. The cryptocurrency fell below $6,000 in earlier trading. It is now down half of its value since just the beginning of the year. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor, Jon Hilsenrath and Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly. Rough day at the office.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY & COMPANY: Yes, it's very interesting though that, you know, stock are declining and G.M. is beating earnings. I kind of --

BARTIROMO: That's sort of the story. It's the --

(CROSSTALK)

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: I'll tell you why G.M. is beating because they sold 20 percent more of their Chevy Equinox as well as their Chevy Traverses.

BARTIROMO: The SUV?

HILSENRATH: The SUVs. They're higher margin products. So, for example, the Chevy Equinox, they sold 20 percent more. The average selling price was $3,000 more than the previous year's version. But, you know, when you look at the markets and we're off the lows right and VIX's hit above VIX uncertainty indicator and last time it hit 50 was in August of 2015. And then the market rebounded from there, so this is really a capitulation and the bottom could be starting to come in as we started to flesh out some of the weaker hands in --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Why do you see a bottom?

HILSENRATH: I think -- well there is a couple --

BARTIROMO: On the horizon.

HILSENRATH: Yes. So I see a bottom one because when VIX hits 50 or above at those extreme levels then it comes down the market rises back up, right? So the stream uncertainty has hit and then it is over.

BARTIROMO: I see

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The markets are more stable than they were last night. The Dow futures at one point were down 750 points and overnight trading but we still have not seen these market gages hit correction territory. The closest would be the Dow transports are down nine percent from the recent record high, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down eight and a half percent. So watch for on the Dow 23,955 and change that would be a 10 percent correction from the recent record.

BARTIROMO: Great info, Dagen. We want to get to this market here because the Dow posted the largest ever single-day point decline in history yesterday. But we have been putting it in context this morning basically saying, yes, four percent is not in the top in terms of the decline, so on a point basis yes it was a terrible day but not so when you look at the overall. President Trump, of course, has touted tax reform and economic growth for the last year and a half and he was in Ohio yesterday doing the same -- Blake Burman is at the White House right now with the administration's reaction to the stock market sell-off. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. You are right. The White House has been touting the stock market at success at almost a daily clip here but yesterday once this rout settled, they tried to hit the pause button for a second and instead take a look at the longer-term picture. The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders putting out a statement which said the following, ''The President's focus is on our long-term economic fundamentals which remain exceptionally strong with strengthening U.S. economic growth, historically low unemployment and increasing wages for American workers. The President's tax cuts and regulatory reforms will further enhance the U.S. Economy and continue to increase prosperity for the American people.'' The Vice President who has just landed in South Korea when he was in route yesterday was asked about this and he said the market drop was due to the ebbs and flows of the market.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The most important numbers to focus on are the fundamentals. The fundamentals of this economy continue to be very strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now the Dow precipitous drop came as President Trump was in Ohio touting tax reform. This is an event that The President would normally talk about the stock market successes but yesterday he did not mention the volatility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Factoring are coming back, everything is coming back they all want to be where the action is. America is once again open for business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Maria, as we saw yesterday The White House is planning still on putting The President out on the road touring this new tax code, new tax bill but yesterday's event could not have come at a worse time realistically for this president because it was one of the rare times that when The President was out there giving a big speech instead the cameras were turning elsewhere as the market was dipping into the red. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Wow. It's tough day for sure. Blake, thank you so much. Blake Burman joining us right now. A Member of the House Appropriations Committee Congressman Chuck Fleischmann of Tennessee. Congressman, good to see you this morning. Thanks for joining us.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R), TENNESSEE: Good morning. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What do you see in terms of this market sell-off? What are the implications here from your standpoint?

FLEISCHMANN: Well obviously I think we've seen unprecedented highs in the stock market, the economy is doing well, unemployment is low. People have more money in their pockets because of the tax cuts. I have never seen fundamentals look so good in a long time. Now we have to be cognizant that the stock market is a market and there is speculation, people invest and then like I think one of the things with the economy doing so well across the board is some people may look for other places to put their money in addition to the stock market. So I think we need to be positive, I think we need to work together. And I think as legislators we need to provide a very conducive environment for business to continue to do well I think we're doing that.

BARTIROMO: I guess what I was asking is, you know, Alan Greenspan, Jon, you know this used to talk about the wealth effect. And this market is up $8 trillion since the election. So, where are you going to buy a C.D. now, I don't know?

BARTIROMO: Remember the days when you had, like, big stores that just sold C.D.s and albums?

KELLY: What am I going to put in my Walkman?

HILSENRATH: I'm feeling pretty old because I'm remembering the days when I was buying record albums.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, Kevin, you were born after the -- right?

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: Oh, my, God, you're busted. Thank you so much, Lauren. Coming up, Iraq (INAUDIBLE). General Jack Keane will join me next to break down what this major troop ship has meant. A drawdown of our soldiers in Iraq. Then. the very latest on the budget showdown and its impact on military spending. Stay right there. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: This has been a volatile morning for markets this is morning, everybody. Take a look at the Futures and what we're seeing, it's real volatile. Dow Industrials' down 243 points; the NASDAQ is firmly in negative territory once again after trading up about half an hour ago, it is now down 44 points, and the S&P 500 is weaker by about 15. We're watching markets on the heels of an 1100 points selloff in the Dow yesterday -- the worst point decline ever.

Shutdown showdown, meanwhile, with government funding set to expire this Thursday. House Republicans are expected to vote on a temporary spending bill later today, that provides Pentagon funding for a full year. The proposal would keep the government open until March 23rd and lift budget caps to provide $659 billion in defense funding. President Trump called on Democrats yesterday to support military spending, that was during his trip to Ohio. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But believe it or not, Nancy Pelosi and those in Congress who want to raise your taxes, they want to raise your taxes, they don't want to give the money to the military where we need it. You know, without the military, we might not be here.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: Or we might not be here for long, believe me.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This coming at the Trump administration is reportedly expected to ask lawmakers for $716 billion for defense spending in the fiscal 2019 budget. Let's talk about the 18 budget and 19 budget right now with Fox News Senior Strategic Analyst, General Jack Keane. General, it's good to see you, sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIST ANALYST: Good to see you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, as a four-star general, as a person who has watched, an expert watch what the military needs, what is your take on what you would like to see out of this Congress this week and beyond in terms of military spending, general?

KEANE: What we absolutely need is to stop the continuing resolution. So, our audience understand as the word continues in resolution applies, what that means is that we're continuing the old funding level. So, we're continuing Obama's old funding levels, which means we only have five out of 58 brigades combat ready. Half the airplanes are not flying due to spare parts. The military is the smallest it's been in 75 years. Not a single penny has been added to the budget in 2018 because they haven't passed an appropriations bill and they continue the resolutions of the past, which means there is no rebuilding of the military. Now, we're talking about going to March which will be six months into this fiscal year with no new money for the military at all.

BARTIROMO: Why can't they get past March 23rd and why can't they come into agreement on this when we all know the threats in this country and against this country have gone straight up?

KEANE: Well, there's a couple of things, there's not consensus on removing sequestration or the budget caps. So, what they'll likely do is temporarily either suspend them or increase the budget cap numbers so the defense budget can go up. The Democrats are pushing back on the defense budget, not in principal -- there's something wrong with increasing defense, but they want to like increase, Maria, in nondefense domestic issues and that is where the political impasse is.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible to me that the Democrats want to stand on this not to support the military. yet Defense Secretary Jim Mattis headed to the Hill, general. He's going to testify before the House Armed Services Committee on the national defense strategy. You were on the Congressional Commission for National Defense Strategy, what do you want to see there and what are your expectations from today's hearing?

KEANE: Well, I've been through that strategy in detail as a part of the commission and we're going to give a preliminary report, and then a final report in a few months. And we actually think the new vector that the administration has and the Defense Department is right on the mark. We're in an era of big power competition with Russia and China, emphasis, long- term strategic competitive China to be sure, rogue states North Korea and Iran, and still maintain the threat of terrorism. This is looking at the world, Maria, as it truly is, crafting a strategy to deal with that and also asking the Congress, give us the resources to cope with that.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and you would think that that's what they want to do, by the way. Let's turn to the war on terror for a moment general. American forces are reducing the number of troops in Iraq, that's according to Associated Press. An Iraqi government spokesperson attributed the U.S. drawdown to defeating ISIS militants in the region. Your reaction, General, where are we?

KEANE: Well, first of all, a troop deserve a lot of praise on what they're able to accomplish, helping the Iraqis, take back that country, which has largely been done. We're reducing troops but we're not ending our troop commitment in Iraq, like the Obama did after the Bush surge was so successful. We're not going to make that mistake.

BARTIROMO: Good point, general, that was a huge mistake. Great to see you, sir, as always. You are a superstar, General Jack Keane joining us. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is --

END

urn:contentItem:5RKP-X8M1-DY0W-4343-00000-00Bitcoin Price Falls Below $6,000 As Banker Signals Crackdown; Dow Bounces Back After Monday's Stock Market Turmoil; U.S. House To Vote On2018-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:13ZLexisNexisBitcoin Price Falls Below $6,000 As Banker Signals Crackdown; Dow Bounces Back After Monday's Stock Market Turmoil; U.S. House To Vote OnLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, February 6th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Breaking news this morning the global sell-off is continuing, futures are indicating a decline at the start of trading this morning of 182 points as three-quarters of 1 percent. And I should point out that that is off of the lows this morning. The NASDAQ is down 15 and the S&P is down six, this comes of course after stocks tumbled yesterday with the Dow posting the largest single-day point decline ever closing down nearly 1,200 points on the day that wasn't the low. The Dow and the S&P 500 wiped out the year's gains with yesterday's performance alone. The declines sending shockwaves across the world overnight and this morning.

First overnight take a look at Asia overnight, markets tip a nose-dive the worst performers were Japan and Hong Kong with the Hang Seng index down better than five percent and the Nikkei average in Japan down four and three-quarters percent. And then there's Europe, markets are open right now and they are trading down. You got steep declines across the board in Europe, the FT 100 down 1.8 percent as you can see the market there hitting the lowest level in over a year. The CAC Quarante is down 2-2/3 percent and the DAX Index down 2-1/4 percent. The turmoil coming as investors are watching earnings this morning from some big names.

General Motors reported earnings and revenue that were above expectations for the fourth quarter. G.M. stock is up 1-1/2 percent, we're also watching Disney because the Walt Disney company is going to be reporting its fourth quarter after the close tonight. We're also watching shares of I'm sorry Bitcoin, the price of Bitcoin is down. The cryptocurrency fell below $6,000 in earlier trading. It is now down half of its value since just the beginning of the year. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor, Jon Hilsenrath and Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly. Rough day at the office.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY & COMPANY: Yes, it's very interesting though that, you know, stock are declining and G.M. is beating earnings. I kind of --

BARTIROMO: That's sort of the story. It's the --

(CROSSTALK)

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: I'll tell you why G.M. is beating because they sold 20 percent more of their Chevy Equinox as well as their Chevy Traverses.

BARTIROMO: The SUV?

HILSENRATH: The SUVs. They're higher margin products. So, for example, the Chevy Equinox, they sold 20 percent more. The average selling price was $3,000 more than the previous year's version. But, you know, when you look at the markets and we're off the lows right and VIX's hit above VIX uncertainty indicator and last time it hit 50 was in August of 2015. And then the market rebounded from there, so this is really a capitulation and the bottom could be starting to come in as we started to flesh out some of the weaker hands in --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Why do you see a bottom?

HILSENRATH: I think -- well there is a couple --

BARTIROMO: On the horizon.

HILSENRATH: Yes. So I see a bottom one because when VIX hits 50 or above at those extreme levels then it comes down the market rises back up, right? So the stream uncertainty has hit and then it is over.

BARTIROMO: I see

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The markets are more stable than they were last night. The Dow futures at one point were down 750 points and overnight trading but we still have not seen these market gages hit correction territory. The closest would be the Dow transports are down nine percent from the recent record high, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down eight and a half percent. So watch for on the Dow 23,955 and change that would be a 10 percent correction from the recent record.

BARTIROMO: Great info, Dagen. We want to get to this market here because the Dow posted the largest ever single-day point decline in history yesterday. But we have been putting it in context this morning basically saying, yes, four percent is not in the top in terms of the decline, so on a point basis yes it was a terrible day but not so when you look at the overall. President Trump, of course, has touted tax reform and economic growth for the last year and a half and he was in Ohio yesterday doing the same -- Blake Burman is at the White House right now with the administration's reaction to the stock market sell-off. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. You are right. The White House has been touting the stock market at success at almost a daily clip here but yesterday once this rout settled, they tried to hit the pause button for a second and instead take a look at the longer-term picture. The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders putting out a statement which said the following, ''The President's focus is on our long-term economic fundamentals which remain exceptionally strong with strengthening U.S. economic growth, historically low unemployment and increasing wages for American workers. The President's tax cuts and regulatory reforms will further enhance the U.S. Economy and continue to increase prosperity for the American people.'' The Vice President who has just landed in South Korea when he was in route yesterday was asked about this and he said the market drop was due to the ebbs and flows of the market.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The most important numbers to focus on are the fundamentals. The fundamentals of this economy continue to be very strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now the Dow precipitous drop came as President Trump was in Ohio touting tax reform. This is an event that The President would normally talk about the stock market successes but yesterday he did not mention the volatility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Factoring are coming back, everything is coming back they all want to be where the action is. America is once again open for business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Maria, as we saw yesterday The White House is planning still on putting The President out on the road touring this new tax code, new tax bill but yesterday's event could not have come at a worse time realistically for this president because it was one of the rare times that when The President was out there giving a big speech instead the cameras were turning elsewhere as the market was dipping into the red. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Wow. It's tough day for sure. Blake, thank you so much. Blake Burman joining us right now. A Member of the House Appropriations Committee Congressman Chuck Fleischmann of Tennessee. Congressman, good to see you this morning. Thanks for joining us.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R), TENNESSEE: Good morning. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What do you see in terms of this market sell-off? What are the implications here from your standpoint?

FLEISCHMANN: Well obviously I think we've seen unprecedented highs in the stock market, the economy is doing well, unemployment is low. People have more money in their pockets because of the tax cuts. I have never seen fundamentals look so good in a long time. Now we have to be cognizant that the stock market is a market and there is speculation, people invest and then like I think one of the things with the economy doing so well across the board is some people may look for other places to put their money in addition to the stock market. So I think we need to be positive, I think we need to work together. And I think as legislators we need to provide a very conducive environment for business to continue to do well I think we're doing that.

BARTIROMO: I guess what I was asking is, you know, Alan Greenspan, Jon, you know this used to talk about the wealth effect. And this market is up $8 trillion since the election. Well now obviously 4-1/2 trillion since the election but that was a factor. Are there implications in terms of economic growth as a result of the sell-off? That is my question.

HILSENRATH: I think as long as market settles down and it looks like it will then that will -- their wealth effect is still in there because we're still talking about net gains for most people on their 401(k) plans. And we're still talking about companies net, seeing their share prices up and being more optimistic about investing and spending money.

BARTIROMO: All right.

MCDOWELL: Well, and also 90 percent of workers in this country this month saying higher wages because of tax cuts so it's not just the stock market but it's also -- they have real cash on hand because of what Congress has done.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it is great, Congressman I mean you did a good job on the tax plan. We're waiting to see the implications of it because we know that people have more money in their pockets but you've got another issue on your hands with this short-term measuring to fund the government. Through March 23rd I've heard another shutdown while funding the defense department for a full year? I mean how can you -- how can you -- how do you justify living from you know one resolution to the next? One continuing resolution to the next?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, as a house appropriator as you know last year we passed all 12 house appropriation bills. We did our job and we want to get back to what we could locally call regular order. In other words, the House and the Senate appropriations committee is doing job passing budgets and getting it down. Unfortunately, we are in an environment largely due to the Senate rules where they need 60 to get something done, we saw Schumer shutdown which I thought was detrimental. It was short thank goodness but it's not easy to get things done right now in Washington, D.C. So we just have to continue to work hard. On part of the House Republicans and house appropriator such as myself we're doing our job, we're going to do it again this year and we're just going to stay at it and we just hope that other people who serve are the legislators in both parties and both bodies do their job.

HILSENRATH: Congressman, two questions for you. First of all on the budget, well, how is this year pass a budget resolution and the budget. Second of all one of the reasons the stock market is falling now is because long-term interest rates are going up, one of the reasons long-term interest rates are going up it seems is that we're looking at budget deficits that are going to exceed a trillion dollars in another year or two. What are Republicans in Congress going to do about a trillion-dollar budget deficits?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, I think fundamentally we need to look long-term at mandatory spending issues, we're seeing the effects, the ill effects of the budget control act which is really squeezed, discretionary spending hurt defense and hurt other domestic spending. But the real problem is that we have seen the dollars available on discretionary side of the budget equation continue to shrink and that is going to happen unless we address this in a larger sense.

HILSENRATH: So what are you going to do to address it?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, I think we need to have everyone from the administration, the Senate, the House Republicans and Democrats actually look to fiscal reform. I think a balanced budget amendment which actually I had the privilege of voting for would be a step in the right direction. Let's face it, I come from a state -- the great state of Tennessee that has a constitutional amendment in a state constitution to balance its budget. We have no debt in Tennessee, if you look at some other states don't have that in their constitutions, they are never going to get out of red I think.

HILSENRATH: How would you balance it what would you cut? You just said you don't want to cut discretionary spending so what would you cut?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, we have to reform I'd rather use the term reform when we look at the whole picture, we have to see where we're spending our dollars that is on the mandatory side of the equation.

BARTIROMO: So Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, talk about interest on the national debt. We're talking about interest rates, pressure on interest rates to go up and I do think you'll see interest rates go up. When you were borrowing -- when you're $20 trillion in debt, if you are a borrow and interest rates go up that is not good, that is not good if you are an individual borrower, that is not good if a country that is borrowing and let's face it we are at a time where other countries like China are buying up our national debt. That is not good.

BARTIROMO: That's a point you have made umpteen times, Dagen in terms of the interest.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but in Congress, what do you do to control the actual interest rate that's paid on the debt? That is -- that is a market unless you are -- unless you are telegraphing to the Federal Reserve that you want the Federal Reserve to --

HILSENRATH: And that is rising now because debt is going up so much.

MCDOWELL: Right. It -- the --

HILSENRATH: Well, the cost of debt that's actually selling off -- the price --

BARTIROMO: But the cost of debt, that is right.

MCDOWELL: The interest on the national debt in a few years is going to surpass what we spend on defense every year. Just that 80 percent of the growth in spending is entitlements and the interest on the debt in the -- over the next decade. So to that point when is anybody going to have the gumption to step up and say OK it is time to get our arms around entitlements? And really you are going to have to -- at some point cut what people receive from the federal government in terms of Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid and Republicans couldn't do it with just Medicaid last year.

FLEISCHMANN: I'd rather again use the term reform, we never want the scare our senior's people 55 and over will be safe and they ought to be safe. But we got to look at the long-term prospects for our country. Also, the numbers are not good, we have baby boomers, people my age and older who are going on through the Social Security and Medicare every day. We need to be protected, we don't need to engage in a game political scare. Right now we are in a very -- most of its time politically, a game of one-upsmanship. So we need to sit down come up with good ideas, we should have done this on healthcare, Obamacare was a budget buster because most of that spending was where? On the mandatory side of the spending equation.

HILSENRATH: It doesn't sound like -- it doesn't like you want to go there on Social Security and Medicare and like that, something you want to talk about actually reforming or cutting.

BARTIROMO: Or after their midterm elections probably. You are going to cut -- are you going to cut these mandatory things during in an election year? I don't think so --

FLEISCHMANN: I don't think so.

MCDOWELL: When is it -- when is it volatile politically? Because you guys are up -- right, you guys are up from re-election every two years. So it is -- it is always -- there is always that hot potato, that football if you will.

FLEISCHMANN: Well, let's look at things that we can all agree on. If we have growth and I think we are going to have growth from this tax cut, we're going to see the economy grow. So that's going to be good for everyone. Employers hiring, unemployment is at an all-time low, we are going to see people with more money if people who have jobs and are spending we are going to see a healthier economy and things will go better that way. So you will have more dollars actually feeding those kiddies that need to be fed. If people are unemployed and we have gone through the great recession that we did, starting in 2008 and they're not feeding these programs in terms -- with the revenue, there is going to be a problem. So growth is going to be a key term factor in this as well as spending reform.

BARTIROMO: All right. So growth is the priority right now we got it. Congressman, it's good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

FLEISCHMANN Great to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Chuck Fleischmann, joining us. We will be right back. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are selling off this morning once again. We are seeing a continuation of that global meltdown yesterday. Dow Industrials down 220 points right now. And futures were expecting they said a tough opening for the stock market. General Motors is out with its latest quarterly earnings this morning meanwhile. That stock is actually up even though we're seeing the rest of the market trade down. Lauren Simonetti with the details there. Lauren?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Maria. Let's first take a look how G.M. shares or trading right now in premarket trading after the company reported better than expected quarterly results on an adjusted basis, $40.02 of share, that's a gain of 48 cents. G.M. did take its charge who does a tax reform $7.3 billion in the quarter. But they have a record operating profit. Thanks to big demand for their profitable pickup trucks and SUVs. Vehicle sales did rise about one percent from a year ago to almost nine million vehicles sold in a quarter. We're going to get results from Dow component, Walt Disney after the close today. Analysts they're looking for earnings for share at about four percent from a year ago, the result expected to get a lift from Thor: Ragnarok and from Star Wars.

Investors going to pay close attention to anything the company says about ESPN, ESPN plus order other streaming services. Shares a Disney down $1.95 in the premarket right now. Well, how low will they go? Bitcoin was plummeting, briefly below $6,000 earlier this morning but then it actually turned positive.
