urn:contentItem:5RKF-DKB1-DXH2-63KW-00000-00Bitcoin Price Falls Below $6,000 As Banker Signals Crackdown; Dow Bounces Back After Monday's Stock Market Turmoil; U.S. House To Vote On Government Funding As Immigration Battle Simmers2018-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:12ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTChuck Fleischmann, Nancy Tengler, Hogan GidleyNEWSFinancial020603cb.231Bitcoin Price Falls Below $6,000 As Banker Signals Crackdown; Dow Bounces Back After Monday's Stock Market Turmoil; U.S. House To Vote On Government Funding As Immigration Battle SimmersMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Kevin Kelly, Jon Hilsenrath, Blake Burman, Lauren Simonetti, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us this morning, I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Tuesday. It is Tuesday, February 6th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Breaking news this morning the global sell-off is continuing, futures are indicating a decline at the start of trading this morning of 182 points as three-quarters of 1 percent. And I should point out that that is off of the lows this morning. The NASDAQ is down 15 and the S&P is down six, this comes of course after stocks tumbled yesterday with the Dow posting the largest single-day point decline ever closing down nearly 1,200 points on the day that wasn't the low. The Dow and the S&P 500 wiped out the year's gains with yesterday's performance alone. The declines sending shockwaves across the world overnight and this morning.

First overnight take a look at Asia overnight, markets tip a nose-dive the worst performers were Japan and Hong Kong with the Hang Seng index down better than five percent and the Nikkei average in Japan down four and three-quarters percent. And then there's Europe, markets are open right now and they are trading down. You got steep declines across the board in Europe, the FT 100 down 1.8 percent as you can see the market there hitting the lowest level in over a year. The CAC Quarante is down 2-2/3 percent and the DAX Index down 2-1/4 percent. The turmoil coming as investors are watching earnings this morning from some big names.

General Motors reported earnings and revenue that were above expectations for the fourth quarter. G.M. stock is up 1-1/2 percent, we're also watching Disney because the Walt Disney company is going to be reporting its fourth quarter after the close tonight. We're also watching shares of I'm sorry Bitcoin, the price of Bitcoin is down. The cryptocurrency fell below $6,000 in earlier trading. It is now down half of its value since just the beginning of the year. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal Global Economics Editor, Jon Hilsenrath and Benchmark Managing Partner Kevin Kelly. Rough day at the office.

KEVIN KELLY, MANAGING PARTNER, KELLY & COMPANY: Yes, it's very interesting though that, you know, stock are declining and G.M. is beating earnings. I kind of --

BARTIROMO: That's sort of the story. It's the --

(CROSSTALK)

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: I'll tell you why G.M. is beating because they sold 20 percent more of their Chevy Equinox as well as their Chevy Traverses.

BARTIROMO: The SUV?

HILSENRATH: The SUVs. They're higher margin products. So, for example, the Chevy Equinox, they sold 20 percent more. The average selling price was $3,000 more than the previous year's version. But, you know, when you look at the markets and we're off the lows right and VIX's hit above VIX uncertainty indicator and last time it hit 50 was in August of 2015. And then the market rebounded from there, so this is really a capitulation and the bottom could be starting to come in as we started to flesh out some of the weaker hands in --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Why do you see a bottom?

HILSENRATH: I think -- well there is a couple --

BARTIROMO: On the horizon.

HILSENRATH: Yes. So I see a bottom one because when VIX hits 50 or above at those extreme levels then it comes down the market rises back up, right? So the stream uncertainty has hit and then it is over.

BARTIROMO: I see

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: The markets are more stable than they were last night. The Dow futures at one point were down 750 points and overnight trading but we still have not seen these market gages hit correction territory. The closest would be the Dow transports are down nine percent from the recent record high, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down eight and a half percent. So watch for on the Dow 23,955 and change that would be a 10 percent correction from the recent record.

BARTIROMO: Great info, Dagen. We want to get to this market here because the Dow posted the largest ever single-day point decline in history yesterday. But we have been putting it in context this morning basically saying, yes, four percent is not in the top in terms of the decline, so on a point basis yes it was a terrible day but not so when you look at the overall. President Trump, of course, has touted tax reform and economic growth for the last year and a half and he was in Ohio yesterday doing the same -- Blake Burman is at the White House right now with the administration's reaction to the stock market sell-off. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you. You are right. The White House has been touting the stock market at success at almost a daily clip here but yesterday once this rout settled, they tried to hit the pause button for a second and instead take a look at the longer-term picture. The White House Press Secretary, Sarah Sanders putting out a statement which said the following, ''The President's focus is on our long-term economic fundamentals which remain exceptionally strong with strengthening U.S. economic growth, historically low unemployment and increasing wages for American workers. The President's tax cuts and regulatory reforms will further enhance the U.S. Economy and continue to increase prosperity for the American people.'' The Vice President who has just landed in South Korea when he was in route yesterday was asked about this and he said the market drop was due to the ebbs and flows of the market.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE PENCE, VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The most important numbers to focus on are the fundamentals. The fundamentals of this economy continue to be very strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now the Dow precipitous drop came as President Trump was in Ohio touting tax reform. This is an event that The President would normally talk about the stock market successes but yesterday he did not mention the volatility.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Factoring are coming back, everything is coming back they all want to be where the action is. America is once again open for business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Maria, as we saw yesterday The White House is planning still on putting The President out on the road touring this new tax code, new tax bill but yesterday's event could not have come at a worse time realistically for this president because it was one of the rare times that when The President was out there giving a big speech instead the cameras were turning elsewhere as the market was dipping into the red. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Wow. It's tough day for sure. Blake, thank you so much. Blake Burman joining us right now. A Member of the House Appropriations Committee Congressman Chuck Fleischmann of Tennessee. Congressman, good to see you this morning. Thanks for joining us.

REP. CHUCK FLEISCHMANN (R), TENNESSEE: Good morning. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: What do you see in terms of this market sell-off? What are the implications here from your standpoint?

FLEISCHMANN: Well obviously I think we've seen unprecedented highs in the stock market, the economy is doing well, unemployment is low. People have more money in their pockets because of the tax cuts. I have never seen fundamentals look so good in a long time. Now we have to be cognizant that the stock market is a market and there is speculation, people invest and then like I think one of the things with the economy doing so well across the board is some people may look for other places to put their money in addition to the stock market. So I think we need to be positive, I think we need to work together. And I think as legislators we need to provide a very conducive environment for business to continue to do well I think we're doing that.

BARTIROMO: I guess what I was asking is, you know, Alan Greenspan, Jon, you know this used to talk about the wealth effect. And this market is up $8 trillion since the election. Well now obviously 4-1/2 trillion since the election but that was a factor. Are there implications in terms of economic growth as a result of the sell-off? That is my question.

HILSENRATH: I think as long as market settles down and it looks like it will then that will -- their wealth effect is still in there because we're still talking about net gains for most people on their 401(k) plans. And we're still talking about companies net, seeing their share prices up and being more optimistic about investing and spending money.

BARTIROMO: All right.

MCDOWELL: Well, and also 90 percent of workers in this country this month saying higher wages because of tax cuts so it's not just the stock market but it's also -- they have real cash on hand because of what Congress has done.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it is great, Congressman I mean you did a good job on the tax plan. We're waiting to see the implications of it because we know that people have more money in their pockets but you've got another issue on your hands with this short-term measuring to fund the government. Through March 23rd I've heard another shutdown while funding the defense department for a full year? I mean how can you -- how can you -- how do you justify living from you know one resolution to the next? One continuing resolution to the next?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, as a house appropriator as you know last year we passed all 12 house appropriation bills. We did our job and we want to get back to what we could locally call regular order. In other words, the House and the Senate appropriations committee is doing job passing budgets and getting it down. Unfortunately, we are in an environment largely due to the Senate rules where they need 60 to get something done, we saw Schumer shutdown which I thought was detrimental. It was short thank goodness but it's not easy to get things done right now in Washington, D.C. So we just have to continue to work hard. On part of the House Republicans and house appropriator such as myself we're doing our job, we're going to do it again this year and we're just going to stay at it and we just hope that other people who serve are the legislators in both parties and both bodies do their job.

HILSENRATH: Congressman, two questions for you. First of all on the budget, well, how is this year pass a budget resolution and the budget. Second of all one of the reasons the stock market is falling now is because long-term interest rates are going up, one of the reasons long-term interest rates are going up it seems is that we're looking at budget deficits that are going to exceed a trillion dollars in another year or two. What are Republicans in Congress going to do about a trillion-dollar budget deficits?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, I think fundamentally we need to look long-term at mandatory spending issues, we're seeing the effects, the ill effects of the budget control act which is really squeezed, discretionary spending hurt defense and hurt other domestic spending. But the real problem is that we have seen the dollars available on discretionary side of the budget equation continue to shrink and that is going to happen unless we address this in a larger sense.

HILSENRATH: So what are you going to do to address it?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, I think we need to have everyone from the administration, the Senate, the House Republicans and Democrats actually look to fiscal reform. I think a balanced budget amendment which actually I had the privilege of voting for would be a step in the right direction. Let's face it, I come from a state -- the great state of Tennessee that has a constitutional amendment in a state constitution to balance its budget. We have no debt in Tennessee, if you look at some other states don't have that in their constitutions, they are never going to get out of red I think.

HILSENRATH: How would you balance it what would you cut? You just said you don't want to cut discretionary spending so what would you cut?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, we have to reform I'd rather use the term reform when we look at the whole picture, we have to see where we're spending our dollars that is on the mandatory side of the equation.

BARTIROMO: So Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid?

FLEISCHMANN: Well, talk about interest on the national debt. We're talking about interest rates, pressure on interest rates to go up and I do think you'll see interest rates go up. When you were borrowing -- when you're $20 trillion in debt, if you are a borrow and interest rates go up that is not good, that is not good if you are an individual borrower, that is not good if a country that is borrowing and let's face it we are at a time where other countries like China are buying up our national debt. That is not good.

BARTIROMO: That's a point you have made umpteen times, Dagen in terms of the interest.

MCDOWELL: Yes, but in Congress, what do you do to control the actual interest rate that's paid on the debt? That is -- that is a market unless you are -- unless you are telegraphing to the Federal Reserve that you want the Federal Reserve to --

HILSENRATH: And that is rising now because debt is going up so much.

MCDOWELL: Right. It -- the --

HILSENRATH: Well, the cost of debt that's actually selling off -- the price --

BARTIROMO: But the cost of debt, that is right.

MCDOWELL: The interest on the national debt in a few years is going to surpass what we spend on defense every year. Just that 80 percent of the growth in spending is entitlements and the interest on the debt in the -- over the next decade. So to that point when is anybody going to have the gumption to step up and say OK it is time to get our arms around entitlements? And really you are going to have to -- at some point cut what people receive from the federal government in terms of Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid and Republicans couldn't do it with just Medicaid last year.

FLEISCHMANN: I'd rather again use the term reform, we never want the scare our senior's people 55 and over will be safe and they ought to be safe. But we got to look at the long-term prospects for our country. Also, the numbers are not good, we have baby boomers, people my age and older who are going on through the Social Security and Medicare every day. We need to be protected, we don't need to engage in a game political scare. Right now we are in a very -- most of its time politically, a game of one-upsmanship. So we need to sit down come up with good ideas, we should have done this on healthcare, Obamacare was a budget buster because most of that spending was where? On the mandatory side of the spending equation.

HILSENRATH: It doesn't sound like -- it doesn't like you want to go there on Social Security and Medicare and like that, something you want to talk about actually reforming or cutting.

BARTIROMO: Or after their midterm elections probably. You are going to cut -- are you going to cut these mandatory things during in an election year? I don't think so --

FLEISCHMANN: I don't think so.

MCDOWELL: When is it -- when is it volatile politically? Because you guys are up -- right, you guys are up from re-election every two years. So it is -- it is always -- there is always that hot potato, that football if you will.

FLEISCHMANN: Well, let's look at things that we can all agree on. If we have growth and I think we are going to have growth from this tax cut, we're going to see the economy grow. So that's going to be good for everyone. Employers hiring, unemployment is at an all-time low, we are going to see people with more money if people who have jobs and are spending we are going to see a healthier economy and things will go better that way. So you will have more dollars actually feeding those kiddies that need to be fed. If people are unemployed and we have gone through the great recession that we did, starting in 2008 and they're not feeding these programs in terms -- with the revenue, there is going to be a problem. So growth is going to be a key term factor in this as well as spending reform.

BARTIROMO: All right. So growth is the priority right now we got it. Congressman, it's good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

FLEISCHMANN Great to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Chuck Fleischmann, joining us. We will be right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are selling off this morning once again. We are seeing a continuation of that global meltdown yesterday. Dow Industrials down 220 points right now. And futures were expecting they said a tough opening for the stock market. General Motors is out with its latest quarterly earnings this morning meanwhile. That stock is actually up even though we're seeing the rest of the market trade down. Lauren Simonetti with the details there. Lauren?

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Maria. Let's first take a look how G.M. shares or trading right now in premarket trading after the company reported better than expected quarterly results on an adjusted basis, $40.02 of share, that's a gain of 48 cents. G.M. did take its charge who does a tax reform $7.3 billion in the quarter. But they have a record operating profit. Thanks to big demand for their profitable pickup trucks and SUVs. Vehicle sales did rise about one percent from a year ago to almost nine million vehicles sold in a quarter. We're going to get results from Dow component, Walt Disney after the close today. Analysts they're looking for earnings for share at about four percent from a year ago, the result expected to get a lift from Thor: Ragnarok and from Star Wars.

Investors going to pay close attention to anything the company says about ESPN, ESPN plus order other streaming services. Shares a Disney down $1.95 in the premarket right now. Well, how low will they go? Bitcoin was plummeting, briefly below $6,000 earlier this morning but then it actually turned positive. So we continue to watch the price of Bitcoin obviously down sharply from 20,000 back in December. Bitcoin has lost more than half of its value this year, there's the chart. This latest selling comes on report of potential price manipulation and hacker activity and lawmakers will explore regulatory oversight for virtual currencies in general at a hearing later this morning.

Let's move on to our final story which has to do with oil prices, they're dropping for a third day. Light sweet crude now at $63.00 a barrel, experts say the global market sell-off actually strengthens the dollar and arising U.S. dollar makes commodities more expensive for foreign buyers. Oil still positive in 2018, taking a look at shares of ExxonMobil, shares of Chevron, both of them are lower in premarket trading.

And Vice President Mike Pence in Japan today. On his way to the Olympics in South Korea and he's delivering a tough message for North Korea. Pence's says he doesn't want North Korea to hijack the games because it's participating on a joint team with South Korea. The Vice President is bringing the father of Otto Warmbier, the American college student who was imprisoned in North Korea for 17 months died last June. Pence also visiting a memorial to the 46th South Korean sailors killed in a 2010 torpedo attack which was attributed to the North Korea.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Lauren. We want to take a break real quick and look at futures as we go to the break. Take a look at this performance after Monday's 1,100 points sell-off in the Dow. We're expecting the Dow to open down almost 300 points this morning better than one percent. The S&P is down three-quarters of a percent as the NASDAQ right now. Plus Mark Cuban speaking out on a stock market fly. Well, the billionaire entrepreneur says he's not worried about the Dow plunge yesterday. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The sell-off in stocks continues this morning after yesterday's historic market plunge, futures are indicating another rough beginning for this market today. Dow Industrials down better than 300 points right, that's 1-1/4 percent. Of course, the Dow suffered its biggest ever one-day point decline yesterday falling nearly 1200 points at the close. Joining us right now is Nancy Tengler, she is Heartland Financial Chief Investment Officer, she's also the author of The Women's Guide to Successful Investing. Nancy, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

NANCY TENGLER, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, HEARTLAND FINANCIAL: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: First, your take on the sell-off, what would you be doing today, what are you telling clients?

TENGLER: We are actually buying, we have taken about five percent out of stocks and bonds on January 2nd, put in non-correlated assets and today we'll be enabling away at large-cap, big names, you know, some of the pharma, some of the Industrials that have -- that didn't --

(CROSSTALK)

HILSENRATH: Why isn't that today the day to buy?

TENGLER: Well, we like -- we called -- I mean, I hate to say this because I'm not a market timer but we had called for a market timer but we had called for a market correction in July, way too early, we just thought we were way ahead of ourselves. I thought the market would sell off in January, I didn't. And so now this is the opportunity we have been looking for.

HILSENRATH: It went up so much since then, why wouldn't it keep going down if we thought it was overvalued in July, isn't it still valued today?

TENGLER: I mean, the fundamentals are super strong. We got earnings revisions from 11 percent this year up to 17.9. The market P.E. on an estimated basis is now at 17 times next year's earnings, if you look at the 10-year it's come down so that's helpful. And we just think the fundamentals are very strong and we want to be owners here.

KELLY: Well, I think if you -- there's the old market ad, right? You take the stairs up the elevator down when it comes to the market so when we see a big fall like this, this gives opportunity to get into a market that's trading at 17 times earnings but we're seeing earnings grow at 20 percent and especially with the dollar coming down. Do you think the dollar is going to be a big tailwind going into the second half of the year to help a lot of these corporations because everyone is talking about one time taxes, you know and we're seeing, you know, that's going to push for the first half but what's the second half of the story?

TENGLER: Yes. That's a difficult one to measure. I mean, we've been beneficiaries of and have written quite a bit about the dollar. Does it stay here? I mean, with cash -- if I'm a CFO, I want the repatriate my crash at these levels, right? So, if that happens and we see foreign investors looking at our yields, I think that becomes a compelling story for maybe a little push-up in dollar, but I don't think it's going to return to the levels we saw a year ago so quickly.

KELLY: I have one more -- so this is the important thing I think about the market, the corporations are buying right now because the blackout periods.

TENGLER: Right.

KELLY: So this is why you want to buy right now because corporations are going to come in and start purchasing.

TENGLER: Yes. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Because they're not buying back their stock now because they're reporting earnings.

TENGLER: Right.

KELLY: Yes. Blackout period.

TENGLER: Right. Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's the point. So, it sounds like you're happy that we have a sell-off because it's giving the investors an opportunity to get back in, this just a sell-off and the fundamentals backed up for the stock market is pretty strong.

TENGLER: Yes. Absolutely. I mean, we wanted to see this, this is like pruning, this is a controlled brush fire, I mean, it didn't feel controlled yesterday on the floor and it a was pretty wild but yes, no, we wanted to see this and this is what we were waiting for because we had to take a lot off the table we were way overweighted.

MCDOWELL: But is there any really way to know given the unprecedented stimulus that you've had for instance for banks around the globe starting with the financial crisis in 2008 of how overvalued asset classes and where people are most exposed. Again, you only find -- found out who is swimming naked when the tide goes out. And that's something with as Federal Reserve really pares back that giant balance sheet as interest rates continue to rise, this could be something that plays out literally over years not just a matter of days.

TENGLER: Agreed. I do agree, Dagen but I do think that we have the benefit of a strong underlying fundamental economy and corporate CEOs that are making actually decent decisions and unexpected decisions with the tax cuts and so I think that's going to provide a floor if you will on-- and with the stock buybacks, I do think that we're going to see continued moves up at least for the next 12 months.

BARTIROMO: Nancy, before you go, you got to talk just about this book, the Women's Guide to Success for Investing, you say that women outperformed men when it comes to investing.

TENGLER: We did. We tend to be a little more deliberate, thoughtful and less risk-focused, not less competitive but less willing to trade and that generates excess return over the long term.

BARTIROMO: Just being patient.

TENGLER: Just being patient buying great companies. Yes.

BARTIROMO: We'll leave it there. Nancy, great insights from you. Thanks so much.

TENGLER: Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Nancy Tengler joining us there. Coming up, the White House weighs in on the global stock market decline, futures indicating another sharp sell-off at the start of trading down 300 points after a stock sell- off yesterday. White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley will join me next live. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news this morning. A global market sell-off continues this morning. Thanks for joining us, everybody. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Tuesday, February 6th. We're an hour away from the open on Wall Street. It has been a volatile morning for stocks. Take a look at futures right now down 350 points. At one point, the S&P and the NASDAQ this morning were actually up. The NASDAQ right now is down 61 points and the S&P down 29 points. So volatility is back and we're expecting another rough open this morning. This, of course, one day after the Dow suffered the worst one-day point decline ever sliding better than four percent, that was almost 1200 points lower on the day. As, you know, 1200 points is the worst point ever but four percent is not. We are seeing this market trade down having said that more this morning. The Dow and the S&P 500 have now wiped out, any gains for 2018 in a day they wiped that out for the 1200-point sell-off. That bloodbath spreading across the world.

Meanwhile, Asia took a cue from the U.S. last night and markets were down sharply. The Nikkei Average in Japan plunged nearly five percent, this is -- this is -- this is not right. What does this Asian markets 2-1/2 percent? That was wrong but we want to tell you the specifics because Hong Kong was down more than five percent overnight and Japan was down almost five percent, more than four percent. These are the closing numbers last night overnight for the Asian markets. So there you go. This is the accurate numbers here. Sorry about that. The market is now down 10 percent from the record-high in Japan, so that is correction mode with that 4-3/4 percent sell-off. In Europe this morning, declines across the board as you can see, the European indices down about two percent apiece. The major markets in London, Paris, Frankfurt all down better than two percent this morning. Joining me right now to talk more about these markets is White House Deputy Press Secretary Hogan Gidley. Hogan, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: Great to see you, Maria. Thanks for the time.

BARTIROMO: So in a statement, the President said he's focused on long-term economic fundamentals, that was yesterday. What is the president's reaction to this market sell-off that we're watching?

GIDLEY: Look, the same that we talked about yesterday is the same today. The fundamentals of the American economy are really strong, some of your guests have alluded to that very fact. This morning we've seen, you know, 7,000 percent increase in the stock market. We heard on the Obama administration that 1.9 percent GDP was the new normal, manufacturing would never come back to our shores. All those things have been turned around in this -- under this president's policy, not to mention the fact GDP is now at -- hovering around three percent for the first time in the better part of the decade. So the fundamentals of this American economy are strong and the American people quite frankly are seeing the effect. He was in Ohio just yesterday talking to the Schafer Corporation, several companies were represented there, giving thousand dollar bonuses to their employees, wages are going up for the first time in eight years, so overall, the soundness of this economy is indisputable.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, look, there's no doubt that the economic backdrop is very strong, we know that, I mean, now for the first time we're hearing expectations of 5.4 percent growth for the first quarter but we also know how focused this president has been on the stock market, right? So does he need to come out and at least calm people down by saying obviously markets go up and down or whatever he wants to say. Billionaire investor Mark Cuban is calling out the president for cheering on the markets but then staying silent during the sell-off. Here is what he said yesterday. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Now the argument is that you talk about on the way up, you own it on the way down. Do you agree with that?

MARK CUBAN, AMERICAN BUSINESSMAN: No, because they should have owned it on the way up and they don't own it on the way down. So, if you're going to go into the market, do your homework, understand what you're getting into and understand all the risks. Where people get hurt is that they don't really do their homework and they don't understand what's involved, particularly when a markets gone straight up for so long and it feels like -- and you have people saying day after that it's going to keep on going straight up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, look, I think Mark Cuban makes a good point, Hogan. What's your take on that?

GIDLEY: Well, look, I mean obviously the president did tout the stock market but I would -- I would hardly say that he focused on it, but let's be honest, I watched yesterday in my office, we have on what your viewers may not know as a quad, so there's a cross on my television with four different networks in the box, I get to watch them all. They went wall to wall with coverage of the stock market declining. Now I understand that's big news but where were they when it was going up? They didn't say a word about that? So, they're trying to discredit this president and his economic prowess on what he's been able to do. You're cutting regulations at a tune to 22 cuts for everyone increase in regulations, that's incredible numbers, it businesses the ability to bring in more jobs, to expand and grow and it gives them a stability they have not had in recent decades. But no question, the president was involved and responsible for the increase in the stock market but also in the overall economy which as you know has been growing at anemic levels under the Barack Obama administration.

BARTIROMO: Right. No, you're right on that for sure. And we're looking at earnings for 2018, going to be up 20 percent largely because of the tax plan and these moves to roll back regulations I get that. Let me -- let me ask you about the budget, Hogan because House Republicans are set to vote today on another short-term spending bill to keep the government open through March 23rd, keep defense spending on track for a year. But they won't address the debt ceiling, of course, it's coming as the Democrats are set to head out for their annual retreat later this week? The budget deadline is Thursday. What's going to happen?

GIDLEY: Well, hopefully, we can get a budget passed as the president has been clear, many times that we want a two-year budget in place for spending caps because we have to fund the military, we have to rebuild it, it was dismantled over the course of the last eight years. The president wants that back in place because the American people deserve protection. We have to protect our allies around the world and this budget right now, the C.R., there's no way to govern long term, the president knows that and he's been out talking about that publicly multiple times but we have to get something in place and as we move closer and closer to that deadline hopefully the Democrats won't hold the budget hostage or the American people hostage for the -- for the hundreds of thousands of people here, who are here illegally and unlawfully.

BARTIROMO: Well, why can't the Congress understand that the American people want the both sides to work together? I mean, this is just outrageous that you can't get things done without any help on the other side. We're waiting on an immigration bill, who knows if they'll come to the table thereafter the president puts something out which was obviously three times what they wanted. And then there is this whole memo story, the White House has confirmed it received the Democrats' response to the controversial document which shows abuses at the top of the FBI, your office has just released a statement saying this, the White House has received a memorandum from the minority members of the House Select Permanent Committee on Intelligence, as stated many times the administration will follow the same process and procedure with the memorandum from the minority as it did last week when it received the memo from the majority. So, Hogan, it didn't take that long with the GOP memo, are we going to see a swift decision and what is in this second memo?

GIDLEY: Well, look, I haven't seen the second memo but I will say it took five days for the Republican memo and the president did what was prudent. He brought in the White House Council, he brought in members of National Security team because it's tantamount to decision he makes at the end of this whether did he classify or not. What it does to the American people if it puts National Security at risk? This president would never ever put American lives at risk for politics regardless of what other people may or may not do. He did that, he went to the proper channels and process and procedure with the first memo. He's going to do the exact same thing with this memo. As it relates to immigration if I may go back for a minute. I did see that Senators McCain and Coons put out a bill recently and I'm just going to say it takes a special kind of piece of legislation to be worse for the American people than the Durbin-Graham bill was.

But congratulations to those two Senators, McCain and Coons because they have constructed something that's much, much worse. It does not protect the American people whatsoever, it gives amnesty to scores of people who are here illegally and it doesn't do anything that the border patrol agent say they need as far as deportation mechanisms and fortunate mechanism, it doesn't build the wall at all. And the secret here is, Maria, walls work, whether it's the one in San Diego that cut illegal crossings by 95 percent or the one in Jerusalem that went around the city that cut illegal crossings by 99 percent, they work and Democrats can't have it both ways, they can't on one hand say, the wall doesn't work, what do we want it for? And then complain that it's going to be built. They know it works because it solves the problem.

BARTIROMO: In fact, the president just tweeting about this right now. And here's what he just said a moment ago. So disgraceful that a person illegally in our country killed at full a person illegally in our country killed @Colts linebacker Edwin Jackson. This is just one of the many such preventable tragedies. We must get the Dems to get tough on the border and with illegal immigration fast. He goes on to say, my prayers and best wishes are with the family of Edwin Jackson. A wonderful young man whose life was so senselessly taken. @Colt. So, Hogan, the president is tweeting about this and yet it seems that the Democrats really do not want to execute anything more from this White House. I mean, let's face it, they do not like him and they do not want him to have success. So what are you going to do?

GIDLEY: Right. It's hard to deal with people when their hatred for -- their personal hatred for President Trump outweighs their desire to see America successful. It kind of blows my mind but look, back to this immigration point, you remember the fight over the C.R. when the Democrats shut down the government, hurting 8.9 million American children, defunding border patrol agents, stopping the funding to military families, they did all of that to protect hundreds of thousands of people who are here unlawfully and illegally as opposed to protecting the hundreds of millions of Americans citizens. That line was drawn in the sand as we approach this new deadline and this new shutdown, you will remember the Schumer shutdown, they wanted -- Democrats said they wanted everything in the C.R., they refused to vote for it. The same thing applies here, the president has put forth policies that are really about a 70 percent in popularity, 80 percent in popularity in some cases.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

GIDLEY: Democrats says they want everything in the bill. So, I don't understand why in the world they would reject this framework when it gives them what they want.

BARTIROMO: Right.

GIDLEY: Unless they just don't want border security and that's what blows my mind.

BARTIROMO: Which is why I think the president has put them in a box a bit here because he is giving them what they want and if they say no, then that means I guess they don't want it. Hogan, real quick in terms of this memo. Let me end there. Are we going to see indictments, are we going to see accountability here? I mean, it's pretty clear at this point that the FBI misled the FISA judge and got a warrant to spy on American citizens so that they could listen in to their competitor, Donald Trump and running the election. So are we going to see indictments? Anybody going to go to jail or have accountability hearing? Also, how far high up does this go? What about Barack Obama, was he setting the rules?

GIDLEY: Well look, it's very obviously that Congress is the investigative arm here and they're -- they seem to be doing their job as far as looking into this but I think all Americans are concerned when the highest levels of the FBI and the DOJ can use the most intrusive invasive surveillance methods against American citizens based on the fact that a Democrat bought and paid for document that was a -- that was a campaign document was used to grant the FISA warrant. That should be concerning to all Americans but I think, Maria, that we're seeing the beginning of this quite frankly and the end. I think the investigation continues, you've Congressman Nunes say that, you've heard Congressman Schiff say that. So I think this is going to continue. It's the start, not the end.

BARTIROMO: So you think then that there will be accountability?

GIDLEY: I hope so and I think the American people deserve that. They want to know that their law enforcement arms in the Federal government are not politically biased, but that they follow the laws and they treat American citizens as they should under the constitution.

BARTIROMO: Well, did the state department follow the laws? Devin Nunes says now he's got an active investigation into the state department, that's Hillary Clinton's state department.

GIDLEY: Right. Again, that's something that Congress is going to have to address but I think it's clear the investigation into Hillary Clinton, there are serious inconsistencies. When you're giving an exoneration letter before you even testify, that's a serious problem and I think all Americans are concerned by that.

BARTIROMO: Right. All right. Hogan, thanks very much. We will see you soon.

GIDLEY: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Hogan Gidley joining us at the White House. As we take a break, take a look at this market, falling out of bed again this morning, down 270 points on the Dow Jones Industrial average. NASDAQ, S&P 500 also weaker there or a handful of firms like RBC, telling clients to buy on the dip after the worst percentage decline yesterday since -- back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures are currently trading lower this morning after the Dow tumbled a record amount yesterday. Look at where we are, Futures expected to be down -- the open, rather, expected to be down 250 points on the Dow at the open. The NASDAQ down 25 points. This, on top of yesterday's nearly 1200-point sell-off, the worst point decline on record, the worst percentage decline of four percent since 2011. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning, waiting for a rough open this morning. Nic?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey, good morning, Maria. So, as you noted, we've obviously had volatility even in the Futures over the last several hours. We're seeing the Futures down 250 points right now. Those two days of selling seven percent. People are already printing out the circuit breakers this morning. A level one would be seven percent. You'd have a 15-minute malt; 13 percent would be the level two; and the 20 percent not that I want that but I'm giving you the news, you shut down for the day.

The big picture also, they're talking about the recent sell-off, why it happened, we know we have a rising interest rate environment. A lot of talk about those who were on the short side of the VIX which jumped 115 percent. And so, obviously, that move historic and weighing in a lot of calls on that one. Margin calls on the -- on the VIX, the people who played the wrong side of that fear index.

Then we have earnings, 55 percent of S&P 500 companies have reported, 77 percent beat on earnings per share, 80 percent on revenue. We're watching for both -- two names, General Motors which came out, did beat on the quarterly results. And they did very well. They've been cost-cutting obviously. The stock is just flat, pretty great in this type of environment and it's been a winner. And Disney after the bell, of course, the $52-billion deal with Fox, revenue rising, and some other news that we'll be watching for them, so watch for Disney after the bell today -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Nic, thank you so much. We're watching that open, for sure. There is a possible upside to this market sell-off. Joining us now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney, looking at the glass half-full, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Look, it's very hard to judge how the market opens when you're looking at these Futures because an exceptionally volatile market, I don't think a -220 tells the full story. I think it's going to be down like a -500 or even a -600 by the time we actually open up this morning. But to follow on from your comment, Maria, I think that might open up the opportunity for some bargain hunting. Now, the big tech stocks have been following our tape.

They're going to be down at the opening bell, doesn't that open up the possibility of the pros coming in, as the amateur sell, the pros come in and buy on what they might think is a bargain price. Apple at 154, Netflix 247, Facebook 178, Amazon below 1400, they are going to be some pros who say, OK, the amateurs got panicked out. We're going to step in, we're going to buy the big text or buy whatever they think is a bargain, watch it run up, and then probably sell it again. What I'm saying is, watch out for the bargain hunters because they're going to be there, and watch out for some exceptional volatility, up and down all day long.

BARTIROMO: Yes, for sure. Well, we've been seeing that volatility just this morning alone, although we had Nancy Tengler earlier, she says she's buying on the dip. A couple other firms out there like RBC telling clients to buy on the dip, so, yes, you're not alone. People seeing opportunity here, for sure, Stu.

VARNEY: It's going to be an extraordinary day, Maria.

BARTIROMO: I love it. We'll see you in 10 minutes, Stu. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart and company, coming up. First though, an Uber for the sky. Why the age of flying taxis could be closer than you think, that's next. And then, Futures this morning, looking like 250 points on the downside at the open this morning. Back in a moment.

SIMONETTI: Welcome back. Crowds pay tribute to a Colorado deputy killed in the line of duty, people lining the streets. And Colorado Springs -- there they are -- to pay respects to Deputy Micah Flick. He was shot and killed while investigating a stolen vehicle. The suspect shot and killed at the scene. Two other sheriff's deputies and a bystander were also shot. Flick was described as an outstanding detective. He leaves behind his wife and 7-year-old twins.

Overseas, prosecutors in Germany searching Audi offices in the investigation into suspected emission manipulation. Audi accuse of fraud and legal advertising for the sales more than 200,000 vehicles in the U.S., as well as Europe since 2009. Investigators say they're focusing on the use of technical means to manipulate the emission levels of certain V6 diesel engines. Audi is the biggest contributor to its parent company, Volkswagen's profit. If you take a look at shares of Volkswagen up about 24 percent from a year ago. Well, who knew, McDonald's French fries may hold the key to treating baldness. According to a new study that examined a chemical that's used in the frying oil. Scientists in Japan say that the silicon chemical can actually mass produce hair follicles when you put it on mice. And they say the simple process is promising and that it could maybe treat hair loss in men. So, I don't know, try rubbing it on your head.

And this one no more straight out of the Jetsons space age cartoon, Bell Helicopter teaming up with Uber to launch the very first air taxes by 2025. So, initial tests are expected to take place in 2020 in Dallas, also in Dubai, Bell Helicopter actually showed off their concept at the Consumer Electronics Show in Vegas last month. Let's take a look at the parents of Bell Textron. Nice chart, shares up 17 percent over the past year. So, I don't know where you want to go with that, but McDonald's helping men with baldness or flying Ubers.

BARTIROMO: All good stories. I'm smarter after your report. Thank you so much.

SIMONETTI: We try.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But we are poorer. Take a look at the Futures right now, we are expecting the sell-off at the start of trading although we are well off of the lows. Take a look, down 151 right now, having come off of a decline of 300 earlier, NASDAQ is now positive, up six points, as we take a break. We'll get our final thoughts from this all-star panel as we see money moving into stocks, and the markets coming off of the lows right now as we speak. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts. Kevin Kelly?

KELLY: We've seen a disconnect between valuation and fundamentals. I think valuation has come down letting credence into the fundamentals in this economy. It could be a buying opportunity.

BARTIROMO: Yes, buying opportunity. Jon?

HILSENRATH: I agree on the fundamentals. The economy looks pretty strong. We had good job's numbers, good wage numbers, good service sector numbers the other day. The economy is in pretty good shape, the market just has to adjust.

BARTIROMO: Dagen.

MCDOWELL: There are some people getting shaken out of this market. There were two exchange-traded (INAUDIBLE) that collapsed overnight where people were betting that volatility would not come back. Again, we see who was naked when the tide goes out.

BARTIROMO: It's back. Volatility is back. Here's Stuart Varney with more on that. Stu, over to you.

Link to Story

February 3, 2020 (Investorideas.com Newswire) Bitcoin's price is likely to continue to rise until the coronavirus peaks, affirms the CEO of one of the world's largest independent financial services and advisory organizations.The comments from Nigel Green, chief executive and founder of deVere Group, comes as the price of the world's most influential digital currency has gained more than 10 per cent in a week.It is also up 30 per cent since the end of 2019, making 2020 the best start to the year for Bitcoin since 2012. To date, there have been 17,335 confirmed cases of the potentially deadly Sars-like virus, including 362 deaths. Mainland China remains the epicentre of the outbreak, although cases have been reported in more than two-dozen countries including the UK, Japan, Thailand, the U.S., Spain, Australia and Germany. Mr Green says: "The ongoing upward trajectory of the price of Bitcoin correlates to the spread of the coronavirus. "The more individual cases that are identified, the more countries around the world that are affected, and the greater the impact on traditional financial markets, the higher the price of Bitcoin has jumped.

"In this regard, we can expect Bitcoin's price is likely to continue to rise until the coronavirus peaks which, according to a prestigious research group in Hong Kong, is likely to be in late April or early May." He continues: "Why have investors been piling into Bitcoin recently? Because it is increasingly regarded as a safe-haven asset in times of uncertainty. "Bitcoin, known as 'digital gold', shares characteristics of the traditional yellow metal including being a store of value, scarce, being perceived as being resistant to inflation, and a hedge against turmoil in traditional markets - many of which have been pushed in a tailspin since the coronavirus outbreak." The deVere CEO says: "Whilst coronavirus and geopolitical tensions have certainly been underscoring the reputation of decentralised, non-sovereign, secure currencies, such as Bitcoin, as safe-havens, they are somewhat peripheral drivers for why cryptocurrencies are now regarded as the future of money. "These key other factors include that they are digital, they are global, they solve real-life issues, big tech and institutional investors are coming off the sidelines, and worldwide demographics - the growth of the native digital generation - are on the side of crypto, meaning the future is, too." Mr Green concludes: "Whilst there will be minor peaks and troughs - as in all markets - I predict the overall trajectory of Bitcoin to remain upward until such time as coronavirus peaks."

BITCOIN predictions from a leading price comparison site point a continuing trend of price rises. The site predicts that BTC will hit $13,511 by April, and $29,533 by the end of December.

GETTY

Bitcoin rose over the weekend20.53 - UPDATE - $25million worth of bitcoin to be sold at US Marshals auction

The bitcoins that will be auctioned were confiscated in "connection with various federal criminal, civil and administrative cases."

The US Marshals will be putting 2,170 bitcoins in the auction, with the sale planning to take place on March 19.

19.12 - UPDATE - Bitcoin starting to rise from $11,500 mark 

According to CoinMarketCap, bitcoin is now starting to rise above the mark it has been bouncing around for a large part of the day. It is now valued at $11,677. 

17.34 - UPDATE - Merriam-Webster has added several cryptocurrency related words to its dictionary

Cryptocurrency, initial coin offering and blockchain have all been added to the dictionary.

15.52 - UPDATE - Latest cryptocurrency scam uses the face of Ryan Gosling 

Chinese company, Miroskii have used a photo of Ryan Gosling to represent its graphic designer who is apparently called Kevin Belanger.

It has come to light, that everyone listed under its meet the team page is a photo of another person with a fake name.

However, most eyes appear to be on Mr Gosling due to his fame.The tagline for Miroskii states it will be the latest cryptocurrency to challenge bitcoin.

According to its website "Miroskii Coin is developed and brought to business by the experts from China, Hongkong, Singapore and Japan to ease the crypto revolution in financial products."

15.36 - UPDATE - World's first whisky cryptocurrency is announced 

A new cryptocurrency has been launched in Scotland which gives investors the chance to own a share of a £40million portfolio of scotch via a new cryptocurrency called CaskCoin.

Each coin will be backed by physical ownership of a share of a cask of scotch.

Ricky Christie CaskCoin operations director said: "With CaskCoin, we are marrying hundreds of years of tradition with cutting-edge technology to provide a unique opportunity to invest in one of the most sought-after whisky portfolios in the world.

"Whisky has a rich history as a store of value and a medium of exchange, and we are building upon this idea with the help of the blockchain and our new CaskCoin cryptocurrency."

AFTERNOON HEADLINES 

Additional reporting by Darius McQuaid

Bitcoin is currently priced at $11,530, marking a $3 drop compared to its price at 7.30 this morning.

Finder.com set up their third edition in a series of monthly panels on how the top 12 cryptocurrencies by market capitilsation and two trending coins will perform in 2018.

The panel predicted that by the end of the year, Ethereum will overtake bitcoin in terms of market capitalisation. They see a 212 percent increase in Ethereum's market capitalisation.

Finder.com believe bitcoin will rise by a large amount but not as much as Ethereum, they think it will see a rise of 194 percent.

Jon Ostler, CEO at finder.com said: "While the downturn has continued over the past month for many coins, our panel is positive that it's coming to an end. All 12 coins listed in this report are expected to increase in value by April 1, 2018, and also rise further by the year's end. While coins like Dogecoin , Cardano and EOS are expected to see greater growth than bitcoin this year, BTC is still forecast by our panel to reach the highest value of the 12 coins, at $29,533.33 by December 31.

"The cryptocurrency market is super volatile and will continue to represent high risk, which is why it's so important to do your research, get professional advice and compare your options before considering purchasing cryptocurrency."

Related articles Diane Abbott savages bitcoin a 'just a gigantic ponzi scheme fundin... Bitcoin WARNING: BoE boss warns cypto regulation is IMMINENT

7.30am MORNING HEADLINES

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of all things cryptocurrency, including price, regulation, innovation and financial crime.

Bitcoin is priced at $11.533 at the start of the day, having risen around $500 since Sunday morning.

Cryptocurrency commentators are still mulling over comments from governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney who said last week that cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin are a "failure" and a lottery.

He said they exhibit all the "classic hallmarks of bubbles" which attract "fools".

Mr Carney said: "The prices of many cryptocurrencies have exhibited the classic hallmarks of bubbles including new paradigm justifications, broadening retail enthusiasm and extrapolative price expectations reliant in part on finding the greater fool.

"At present, crypto-assets raise a host of issues around consumer and investor protection, market integrity, money laundering, terrorism financing, tax evasion, and the circumvention of capital controls and international sanctions."

However, Kevin Murcko, CEO of cryptocurrency exchange, CoinMetro agrees that although Mr Carney's words were harsh, regulation is needed.

He said: "We have long believed that cryptocurrencies should be held to same standards as traditional fiat currencies, especially when it comes to active trading.

"The core content of Carney's speech, which although highly negative and damning, does call for further regulation. This shows us that a legal financial framework for the crypto space is quickly becoming a reality."

He adds: "Strong regulation backed by respected institutions is important to deliver stability to the market. This can only benefit investors in the longer term. For any currency to thrive, it requires liquidity and meaningful movement of tokenized securities.

"This is something that cryptocurrencies have struggled with due to the unregulated and costly infrastructure that currently supports their issuing, holding and trading. The current volatility that we've witnessed across the crypto markets is in large part caused by a lack of regulation and uniformity in how these are traded.

"What's important is that central banks don't snuff out the crypto industry. Contrary to what some believe, it is only in its infancy, and will only continue to grow."

Updates below throughout the day....

12.45pm - UPDATE - Support for BofE 

Nigel Green, founder and CEO of deVere Group, has added to the chorus of support for the Bank of England's plans to regulate crytocurrencies, arguing that the approach is "proactive and pragmatic", and "should be championed".

He said: "The Bank of England is one of the world's most influential central banks and, as such, its approach is likely to help shape the policies of others."

Mr Green argues that strong regulatory frameworks will give investors even more protection and more confidence in the market the comments by the BoE Governor on the regulation of cryptocurrencies will help fuel a sustainable recovery of the likes of Bitcoin, Ethereum, Ripple, Litecoin and Das."

10.59am - UPDATE - Bit of a dip?

BTC has dipped a little to $11,482. Ripple is back above the $1 mark at $1.06, and Ethereum is at $863.

9.43am - UPDATE - Would you pay using Amazon-coin?

Over half of respondents in a new LendEDU survey said they would use an Amazon-created cryptocurrency for purchases on the site.

More than 58 percent of Prime users said they would consider using "Amazon Coins," while  45 percent are open to possibly using Amazon as their primary bank account.

Big tech innovators are perhaps the best placed to bring cryptocurrencies into mainstream use as a means of exchange but so far they've been reluctant to embrace the challenge.

8.47am - UPDATE - North Korea offsets international sanctions with crypto gains

North Korea is believed to have made $200 million in digital cryptocurrency transactions last year, helping the rogue nation to offset the economic impact of US-backed international sactions over its nuclear and missiles programme.

North Korea's huge haul of 11,000 Bitcoins was revealed by Priscilla Moriuchi, a former US National Security Agency officer, in an interview with Radio Free Asia.

Ms Moriuchi told Vox.com: "I would bet that these coins are being turned into something - currency or physical goods - that are supporting North Korea's nuclear and ballistic missile programme."

urn:contentItem:5WJ7-DFJ1-JB4M-V23R-00000-00Bitcoin slides after Fed chair says Facebook's cryptocurrency raises 'serious concerns';Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said Facebook's planned Libra cryptocurrency poses potential risks to the stability of the financial system.2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:12ZLexisNexisBitcoin slides after Fed chair says Facebook's cryptocurrency raises 'serious concerns'Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell said Facebook's planned Libra cryptocurrency poses potential risks to the stability of the financial system.Hamza Shaban

The price of bitcoin fell by more than 10 percent after the chair of the Federal Reserve told Congress that Facebook's planned cryptocurrency raises "many serious concerns."

Bitcoin, the world's top cryptocurrency by market capitalization, sank following Chair Jerome H. Powell's remarks, but the digital currency has surged this year, in part because of Facebook's announcement of its own proposed virtual currency, Libra. Experts say Facebook's momentous entrance could accelerate the adoption of alternative currency and payment systems, lifting the prospects of other cryptocurrencies in the process.

Despite the sudden rise in investor optimism, not everyone was thrilled with Facebook's intentions. When Libra was announced last month, the plans drew immediate scrutiny from regulators in the United States and abroad. The chairwoman of the House Financial Services Committee, Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.), called on Facebook to halt development of its cryptocurrency project until various policy concerns could be addressed.

On Wednesday, Powell confirmed that the Fed has reservations of its own. "While the project's sponsors hold out the possibility of public benefits, including improved financial access for consumers, Libra raises many serious concerns regarding privacy, money laundering, consumer protection and financial stability," he said. "These are concerns that should be thoroughly and publicly addressed before proceeding.

Hours later, President Trump also sharply criticized Facebook's plans to enter the cryptocurrency market, tweeting that the United States has "one real currency" and suggesting the social-networking giant may need to submit to heightened banking regulation.

Bitcoin fell to $11,658 as of Thursday morning, according to market data from Coindesk.

"We are very much aligned with Chairman Powell on the need for governments, regulators, central banks, non-profits and others to be able to ask questions, share concerns and provide feedback on this project," said Facebook spokesman Andy Stone. "This is why we, along with the 27 other Founding Members of the Libra Association, made this announcement so far in advance, so that we could engage in such constructive conversations."

Powell said that the Federal Reserve has set up a working group to assess the risks that Libra may pose to the financial system. He added that the Fed is coordinating with other U.S. regulatory agencies and central banks around the world to study the potential effects. "The process of addressing these concerns, we think, should be a patient, careful one and not a sprint to implementation," he said.

Facebook has described its cryptocurrency project as an empowering tool for people who lack access to financial services, especially in the developing world. The company plans to make the currency available to its 2.4 billion global users, with a digital wallet accessible through Messenger and WhatsApp, in addition to a stand-alone app.

"With Libra, anyone with a $40 smartphone and connectivity will have the ability to securely safeguard their assets, access the world economy, transact at a much lower cost, and over time access a whole range of financial services," David Marcus, the head of Facebook's cryptocurrency initiative, said in a blog post this month.

Marcus said that Facebook announced plans for Libra well ahead of its release to encourage an "open discussion."

But Powell's remarks highlight the potential roadblocks ahead. Washington's fresh concerns over Facebook's push into financial services comes as lawmakers and consumer watchdogs are ratcheting up their criticism of Silicon Valley. Democrats and Republicans have expressed heightened concerns over a range of issues that intersect with Facebook's business, from the spread of misinformation online, to consumer privacy and market concentration.

Last month, Trump continued his attack against big tech companies, suggesting that the federal government should take Google and Facebook to court, potentially on antitrust grounds. Several Democratic candidates vying for the White House have also seized on the backlash against major tech platforms, focusing on concerns of monopoly and labor relations. Presidential hopeful Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) has called for the breakup of Facebook and other tech companies that she says have grown too powerful.

How Washington's souring mood will apply to Facebook's cryptocurrency ambitions may reveal itself soon. Two congressional committees - one in the House and one in the Senate - plan to hold hearings next week to examine Facebook's Libra.

Tony Romm contributed to this report.

"These are concerns that should be thoroughly and publicly addressed before proceeding."

Hours later, President Trump also sharply criticized Facebook's plans to enter the cryptocurrency market, tweeting that the United States has "one real currency" and suggesting the social media giant may need to submit to heightened banking regulation.

Bitcoin fell to $11,658 as of Thursday morning, according to market data from Coindesk.

"We are very much aligned with Chairman Powell on the need for governments, regulators, central banks, non-profits and others to be able to ask questions, share concerns and provide feedback on this project," said Facebook spokesman Andy Stone. "This is why we, along with the 27 other Founding Members of the Libra Association, made this announcement so far in advance."

Powell said the Federal Reserve has set up a working group to assess the risks that Libra may pose to the financial system. He added that the Fed is coordinating with other U.S. regulatory agencies and central banks around the world to study the potential effects. "The process of addressing these concerns, we think, should be a patient, careful one and not a sprint to implementation," he said.

Facebook has described its cryptocurrency project as an empowering tool for people who lack access to financial services, especially in the developing world. The company plans to make the currency available to its 2.4 billion global users, with a digital wallet accessible through Messenger and WhatsApp, in addition to a stand-alone app.

"With Libra, anyone with a $40 smartphone and connectivity will have the ability to securely safeguard their assets, access the world economy, transact at a much lower cost, and over time access a whole range of financial services," David Marcus, head of Facebook's cryptocurrency initiative, wrote in a July blog post.

But Powell's remarks highlight the potential roadblocks ahead. Washington's fresh concerns over Facebook's push into financial services comes as lawmakers and consumer watchdogs are ratcheting up their criticism of Silicon Valley. Democrats and Republicans alike have expressed heightened concerns over a range of issues that intersect with Facebook's business, from the spread of misinformation online, to consumer privacy and market concentration.

Last month, Trump continued his attack against big tech companies, suggesting the federal government should take Google and Facebook to court, potentially on antitrust grounds. Several Democratic candidates vying for the White House have also seized on the backlash against major tech platforms, focusing on concerns of monopoly and labor relations. Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), a presidential hopeful, has called for the breakup of Facebook and other tech companies that she says have grown too powerful.

How Washington's souring mood will apply to Facebook's cryptocurrency ambitions may reveal itself soon. Two congressional committees - one in the House and one in the Senate - plan to hold hearings next week to examine Facebook's Libra.

Mar 16, 2015( Legal Futures: http://www.legalfutures.co.uk Delivered by Newstex) <nl/> 16 March 2015   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/latest-news/bitcoin-specialist-abs-rides-litigation-wave-from-volatile-digital-currency/print/ <nl/>   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/latest-news/bitcoin-specialist-abs-rides-litigation-wave-from-volatile-digital-currencyBitcoin specialist ABS rides litigation wave from volatile digital currency   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Richard-Howlett.jpg<nl/>Howlett: difficult to explain to High Court judges<nl/><nl/>A partner at a small West London firm has taken 'niche' to a new level by specialising in litigation resulting from the first few turbulent years of digital currency bitcoin.<nl/> Richard Howlett, partner at alternative business structure Selachii, told Legal Futures he is acting for groups of clients who had lost money following the collapse of the leading bitcoin exchange Mt.Gox, based in Japan, and two UK exchanges, Moolah and MintPal.<nl/> He said the absence of any regulation put people at risk. 'We are known as the solicitors people come to for advice. This is such a new concept. It's difficult to explain to a High Court judge what a bitcoin is.'<nl/> Mr Howlett said some of the litigation work was high value, involving sums of over £1m. Along with 39 Mt.Gox clients, he said he had advised almost 50 others on non-contentious bitcoin matters since Selachii was set up in 2013.<nl/>   http://www.part36insurance.co.uk/<nl/>'Lots of clients want to set up in the UK and abroad, and they come to us.

A group of people flew over from Poland last week for a two-hour meeting, who want to set up a new exchange here.<nl/> 'Our turnover increases every month and it gets busier all the time. We are currently on course to increase turnover by 100% from our first year of trading.'<nl/> Mr Howlett, the HOLP and HOFA of Selachii, said the Notting Hill firm was the first to accept direct payments by bitcoin, using a 'virtual wallet'.<nl/> 'Other firms refer bitcoin payments to a third party, which converts it into normal currency,' he said. 'We don't do that. We hold the bitcoins as investments, in the hope their value will gradually increase. Values can go up and down during the day.'<nl/> Mr Howlett added that Selachii meant 'sharks' in Latin, which he said could be interpreted 'in different ways'.<nl/> Eitan Jankelewitz, associate at another bitcoin pioneer, Sheridans[1] in Soho, said 95% of his work with bitcoins was non-contentious.<nl/> 'We've got loads of work. Business is growing and it shows no sign of stopping. Our clients are generally companies. They could be bitcoin exchanges or 'mining' companies - the companies that process transactions. They could be custodians, who operate secure storage systems, or people who publish consumer 'wallets'. They could also be digital agencies who develop creative media for bitcoin.'<nl/> Mr Jankelewitz said that although bitcoin-related work probably accounted for no more than 25% of his work by fee income, the firm offered discounts to businesses 'because in five years' time we believe these businesses will be successful'.<nl/> He said the big tech firms in the USA were investing in bitcoin, and PayPal and Dell had already done deals involving the currency, while IBM was taking a growing interest.<nl/> The associate added that Sheridans accepted payment by bitcoin, but used a payment processor to take away the 'volatility of the currency'.<nl/> By Nick Hilborne[2]<nl/> Tags: alternative business structure[3], bitcoin[4], High Court[5], niche firms[6]<nl/> [ 1]: http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/latest-news/law-firm-accepts-digital-currency-payment-but-continues-invoice-sterling [ 2]:   http://legalfutures.co.uk/nick-hilborne [ 3]:   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/tag/alternative-business-structure [ 4]:   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/tag/bitcoin [ 5]:   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/tag/high-court [ 6]:   http://www.legalfutures.co.uk/tag/niche-firms

Bitcoin prices were falling again Monday. Here's everything you need to know in crypto news.

It was another tough start to the week for bitcoin, which shed as much as 8.5% of its value Monday, Jan. 22. While the cryptocurrency was still firmly above the $10,000 threshold, it remained solidly off its record near $20,000 set last month.

These are the headlines you can't afford to miss on Monday, Jan. 22.


Korea's Korbit Halts Foreign Deposits

Korean crypto exchange Korbit has barred non-citizens from depositing the Korean won on its platform, according to an announcement from the company. Korbit said the move is in order to comply with local anti-money laundering regulations, and the new law will go into effect at the end of this month. Once the regulation takes hold, only Korean citizens with a Shinhan Bank account will be able to use the Korbit exchange platform.


Canada Tests Ethereum

Canada's National Research Council it's testing out the Ethereum blockchain to record government contracts. The NRC will use the Catena platform from bitcoin startup Bitaccess to publish information for the public to see regarding government contracts, grants and contributions. This will be a trial on the blockchain technology for the Canadian government, which will test how else it can be best utilized in other federal operations.


Could Facebook Go Open Source?

As pointed out by , Facebook Inc.CEO Mark Zuckerberg wrote in a the following: "With the rise of a small number of big tech companies...many people now believe technology only centralizes power rather than decentralizes it." Zuckerberg continued in the post to detail his company's willingness to go deeper into exploring open-source, people-empowering technologies such as cryptocurrencies and encryption, Coindesk reported. Could Zuck soon be rolling out his own crypto token? Coindesk thinks it's possible. Look out, - here comes FBCoin?


Facebook is a holding in Jim Cramer's Action Alerts PLUS Charitable Trust Portfolio. Want to be alerted before Cramer buys or sells FB? Learn more now.


Grayscale's Stock Split for Bitcoin

Grayscale Investments, the firm behind the Bitcoin Investment Trust , announced the launch of a of the trust's issued and outstanding shares. The split will take place Friday, Jan. 26, leaving shareholders with 90 shares for each original share held. The move is aimed at making shares of the trust more affordable and attracting retail investors. Ahead of the split, shares of GBTC were worth about $1,685. They'll end this week closer to $16.85 each. Shares of the trust were lower 4.6% late Monday.
